header.activity: Acquaintances getting to know each other better.

speaker.dialect_rep: I may have a slight Somerset accent
speaker.occupation: retired artist and antique dealer/gallery owner

speaker.fls: French -- to A-level, no recent use

body.u: there we are good morning
good morning
erm and erm I see from your form that you were born in in Australia
mm yes
so can you tell me er erm how er how old you were when you left Australia?
yes well if I can go back a step just to explain both my parents er are English
yeah
or were English and they met on a ship going out
right yes
and erm my father was a clergyman and he'd signed on for five years of poverty chastity and obedience in a b what was called the Bush Brotherhood in
right right oh

and erm so it was a bit inconvenient really that he met my mother going out but anyway they kept in touch for five years and at the end of his five years of going around the bush erm he they got married
right
and er and then the war came and he was a chaplain in the Australian army and then erm we lived in two two parishes in and came back to England when I was seven
oh right
and that was quite hard for my mother because she'd left all her family behind
right

cos the whole family had emigrated but not together she'd gone separately erm so anyway that that's what happened and and we ended up in actually because my father had to look for a parish and for us to live somewhere erm and so I spent most of my childhood in in just over the border from actually so we used to do our shopping in so coming to live in was a little bit like coming home

yes I see it's it's it's a a bit weird because we've got similar circumstances cos my father was actually erm he he became a padre in the army erm but but he was also a vicar and we moved from when I was seven erm and erm we went to Germany for three years
really?

and another thing that I can draw a parallel with is that when we came back from Germany cos he did three years that's all it was a sort of er appeal from the bishop for erm clergy to go abroad and when we came back there was no living for us and we had to look for one and that was extremely difficult we ended up living in
oh goodness me
isn't it strange?

well there's a bigger coincidence because when we came back from Australia we had to sort of stay with various people and we came to and stayed in erm the on the edge of the park can't think of the name of the road
erm ?
yeah we caught with a former colleague of my my mother's and erm dad went to see the bishop of
right
to look for a living
really?
and one of the livings that was available was
was it?
yes
how weird
that is probably not just after your father left it because I'm I'm a lot older than you so it would've all happened before
right before how weird
yes yes
isn't the life's full of coincidences isn't it?
it is but it but I think I don't know why he decided against it it just didn't feel right presumably and we ended up actually in a lovely place on the coast near
oh oh wow yes
he had two parishes
oh right course is very I mean the war the horrible war story there and the tragedy of yes
yes yes yes well at the time that wasn't the facts weren't really known
ah it was all secret then wasn't it?
it was a bit secret
yeah

and er but while we were there erm the commemoration erm stone was put up but still people didn't really know the full details unless they'd lived there all their lives and and I don't think anybody ever told us how it really happened
right no no it's come out a lot recently hasn't it?
it has yes
erm and erm you know it it was one of those things that you just couldn't they just couldn't erm they were having an exercise I believe weren't they?
yes yes
and then the U boat came up and and and saw them exercising and wiped a lot of them out it was just terrible
that's right yes yes yes
erm but you must have had a a very interesting childhood what did you what do you remember of Australia then?
erm well just a few impressions really erm er not a lot I remember going to school and it was rather sort of marshal we had to do exercises in the playground we went in to to music
yeah

erm and I just remember playing and er remember doing in a vicarage which had had a tennis court but it was terribly overrun and er overgrown rather erm my parents decided they'd have some chickens but of course the wire netting had all gone in the corners and all the chickens escaped so it was pretty
oh right yeah
erm I had lots of cousins and I still do and I get a little visit from time to time
right
in fact erm at a recent count I had seventeen first cousins
really?
yes
seventeen?
but they lived a long way away
yes yes

and and er so we didn't see them often but that w that was nice so I d I vaguely remember things but not not anything very spectacular I remember the planned visit of erm I think Princess Elizabeth as she then was
right oh right
we were all issued with medals which I still have
oh
but she but she didn't come because her her father died
oh
erm I do remember that I remember being attacked by erm kookaburra
oh right
but it it's put me off birds flying around for life
I'm sure I'm sure
erm but thethey are a little bit possessive of their nests they get a bit aggressive
yes
erm but I can't really remember many things I remember sort of visits to other members of the family and
yes what about erm did you ever go sort of on on a f sheep farm or erm one of those large sheep farms they have in in the centre of Australia?
no
no visits there?
no we were in
right
I suppose there were sheep farms but I don't remember them as being anything very special
yes no no
I do remember f having t to take a plane to get to Sydney a little tiny plane
oh right yes
that was cos that was quite a long way away for us
right er were you are you interested at all or have you read in in the past the works of Nevil Shute?
yes a tiny bit yes
and A Town Like Alice
well that was I think the town or the area where my father was and so it was very interesting
oh was it? yes oh I've I've been I've rediscovered Nevil Shute a while ago actually
ah
I read them all when I was about sixteen and I've rediscovered them all a while ago
yes

erm and I've started rereading them but I really must keep up on that because it's amazing how clear they are in my head yet still I miss so much in my memory and going back to Nevil Shute is wonderful
mm mm yes
erm and of course it's what I'm going forty year forty years ago when I read the last book and and of it's even more eer of an era almost vintage stuff really
yes yes it's a good idea to go back and reread because I think the first time you read you read for the story don't you?
yes you do yes
the second time you you read as much for the story as for the detail or the detail as much as the story

do you find that too with watching drama on television? because some of the Morse for instance and the Lewis erm series I don't know whether you like them but erm we find and the Frost the good series a good drama series we find that we don't watch them we when we watch just one for the second time which we try not to do but we do I always say to my husband I'm watching them for the acting I love the acting the way they play the parts so it's so good and how they inter react with the other characters and that I find absolutely fascinating which like you say I'm not looking for the narrative because I know really what happens cos I've seen it before
mm mm yes ah yes yes yes

erm you you see the erm the frisson between erm Lewis and er his sidekick erm and how they talk to one another and the body language and everything is just right er and and also the actors have evolved that over time they've started to work together so much that they they're actually in a relationship as the part rather than acting the part
yes
so it's very good

oh yeah yes that's that's an interesting aspect my my husband doesn't like Mor didn't like Morse he didn't like his voice for some reason but erm I enjoy l cos we lived erm in before we came here and I've worked in
oh right
and erm I look for the bits of that we know
yes
and that that makes it fun
yeah and that really does make it fun I mean in the same way I went to school in eventually and they did the Eddie Shoestring series from
oh right oh

and I mean that's a long time ago and that was all around at all places I knew and there's that wonderful feeling of you're actually involved in it because you know the places so well I walked down you know every day or whatever
yes yes yes
erm and so there is that lovely feeling
yes
but tell me about then tell me about erm your work cos
right well I went to because I was I was working in and then intere got interested in cleft palate
oh right

and there was a erm well was a centre of excellence for that so I I applied for a job there and erm it was very interesting working in cleft palate though thing was there's well the whole job was just too huge for one person to do and we were terribly terribly underfunded erm for speech and language therapy and erm yeah I was pulled in the direction of cleft palate but also neurology neurosurgery elderly paediatrics
right
it was it was impossible and looking back it it you know I I find it erm difficult really to see how I actually got through it all
yes yes of course yes of course

it was but anyway the I tried to give the cleft palate priority erm because I was working with a a surgeon who was very very eminent and did research and and erm that involved me as well to an extent but it it was it was quite hard but being in I just loved I just loved going out at lunchtime if I had the time to just walk through the streets and and look at the architecture and everything it was it was really beautiful
yes
we lived in a village outside er seven or eight miles out near
right
and erm so travelling in and out was was quite difficult traffic is dreadful

yes it's like I mean we've just been to for the weekend and oh my goodness the traffic is a problem and we decided the hotel we usually stay in has got so expensive cos they've had a refit and so and I decided to to stay outside and then that's a problem cos you've got to keep getting in all the time
oh yes

erm but we went to some really good lectures erm the erm it was really really good erm so we enjoyed that but getting back to then so the question I'd like to ask you about cleft palate erm how did you manage obviously there's so much surgery involved with cleft palate so obviously you've got to wait until the end and the surgery's be done been done so you can start working with the patient on their speech?
well erm not exactly because you would attend the combined cleft clinic
right
erm where there was a surgeon and maybe an orthodontist you know
right

erm and others involved in the care and in fact I would see erm the moms and erm just on their first the baby's first admission just to say hello who who I am and as a the surgeon would have explained what was gonna happen erm but with this surgery the recent surgery much many of the children had normal speech
right
it was fantastic but I my job was to monitor that
right yes
and if there was any sign that any more input was needed
right
erm at a certain stage then I would I would be involved not personally necessarily because erm the hospitals covered a wide wide area including at that time
oh yes

so I would contact the local speech and language therapists and ask them to do some work with a child if necessary erm but the results erm were very much better in the later years I worked there for ten years in the early years there was a type of surgery which erm left a very good result as far as parents was concerned but less good speech results
right yeah
we did some some research and looked at that and it was quite clear that that was not the way to proceed
no
and so the surgeon erm worked erm very early in repairing the cleft
right right
so the child had a normal anatomy to use as speech developed
yes yeah yeah oh erm I suppose the the the most vital part of it all and I used to work on ENTs years ago
oh did you?
yeah it's closing up the hole in the cleft isn't it?
yes
so the the the whistling and the noise isn't isn't coming down through through the opening
yes yes
erm and I always thought and also then obviously food gets inhaled and it it it must be a terrible thing to have
yes it was and the the the feeding is a real problem for some children
yes
there are various teats as you probably know
yes yes
various ones developed for for cleft children but erm the surgeon I worked with was closing the front of the cleft very very early
right
so the child would have a normal hard palate to press the the tongue tip against
right yes
erm they used to make plates to put into sometimes didn't they to close erm the front palate?
yes yes
but I don't know I I'm now very out of date because it's so it's ten years since I retired and it's oh a very long much longer time since I had any contact with cleft
yeah yes yeah and so you went on after that to do erm a more general erm you know stroke victims and that that type of?
yes I I when I came here to erm I came to erm and worked here for ten years er because I wanted to do some management
right yeah oh right
so I managed as speech therapist there in and that limited erm my own clinical work
absolutely yeah
but I was expected to do fifty percent clinical work which is I mean sheer impossibility
yes I can understand that
erm but anyway I did keep up a little bit of cleft work but mainly worked in community hospitals
right
with elderly people
right
but they're not necessarily elderly people some were people with younger people with voice problems
right
erm and well anyhow the head injuries like that ongoing rehab
yes yes yes

so in in a way it was a good thing that I had to keep up my my clinical work because after ten years I'd felt I'd had enough of working as a manager because the budgets were getting tighter and we were expected to do more with less basically and of course the situation's got much much worse since I left
yes oh yes
erm anyway I wanted to work part time partly because I wanted to spend some time with my husband
yes yes
he had been retired oh a very long time and also my mother was ninety living in so we decided to go back to
right right ah
and I got a part time job in community hospitals
oh
and I worked there for eight years and it was lovely I worked three days a week
yes
they gave me a day for mom and a long weekend so we could enjoy
yes
and I I just loved driving around and I loved meeting the people in community hospitals
yes
and after being a manager I really relished the erm clinical again
yeah I can see that you did because as soon as you started talking about it your face lit up and it was like oh this is the best thing I've ever done was it the best thing you've ever done?
yes erm I don't know I enjoyed the challenge of the management and I I think I achieved a lot well it was im imposed the changes were imposed
yes yes
but we we went along with them and did them and I think ended up with quite a good service
great
which then got cut and they'd broken up
ah yes
and anyway that's but yes I think I became a better clinical therapist in a way having been a manager
yes
it made me think differently
yes

erm I always thought value for money when I after being a a manager er and doing my clinical work you know if I'd would it have been worthwhile erm which made me in a way more objective and I was more easily able to manage a a pretty impossible caseload because of that
yes

erm and I think people also because I was then older erm they enjoyed relating to somebody older who had life experience because so many of them would say oh wow she was such a sweet young girl you know therapist
yes yes
but she was so young you know I think the young therapists are remarkably mature when I compare myself eh with them when I was that age they are amazing people and erm and very academic these days
yes
but I think being older helped also in you know when you're relating to to the families as you as you do and to carers at residential nursing homes
mm yes
they have a bit more respect for you cos you're older and you've obviously seen life
absolutely
and I suppose you have more confidence as well
well that's right that's right I mean the confidence only comes with experience
yes
I mean it's it's erm it's it's like you go to a young doctor and erm he hasn't really learned the tricks of the trade yet and they're I mean there are in in all walks of life ways of doing things
yes

erm and erm you know er I just changed from a very young doctor to an older doctor erm because erm ah I my erm my er care was mismanaged to such an extent that we lost our erm our private medical insurance
oh
erm I was given a a a drug that gave me a erm stroke and TIA erm just a small stroke you know
mm

erm but I did I did on two occasions I reported speech erm I I couldn't think of the right words and also my speech was slurred and erm I erm I reported it oh you know given I think it's a bit slurry my speech oh he said oh no no give it another go and I I did and then I had the stroke and then erm and then erm we were was in the process of retiring and we were leaving the company scheme after thirty thirty-five years the company erm medical insurance scheme and we were going on to somebody else and erm my doctor I had the stroke the the the erm the actual scheme came into effect on one day erm and it was the day erm before I had the stroke but she insisted that I'd had it earlier and he put it down and therefore that was the end of my insurance and he couldn't see that from a humanitarian purpose but an elder doctor would have said when did you have the stroke? would've taken my word for it and er but it made a huge difference and that was it so now I can't have private health insurance
mm

and so but but there's been lots and lots of mistakes in that regard there've been so many mistakes with that surgery that I couldn't stand it any longer and it was more stressful going to them so now I've booked in with another doctor who well unfortunately I saw him for the first time last week and he's okay he's much older I I didn't choose him they they they won't let you choose
oh yeah
I wanted a female actually I thought it'd be much better at my age if I see a lady doctor I mean it'd be much better but they wouldn't anyway there you go
mm
erm and so we go on you know
yes
but erm it it's just erm yes it's it's
that's a really awful experience you just had

erm just interesting what you said about value for money and also the two aspects of that and the way your face brightened up when you were saying erm about that because in the last two years running the gallery was the best thing that I ever did
oh was it?

and every time anyone asks me about it I brighten up and say it was the best thing I ever did and value for money was key point because if people were coming in to buy art which they did erm I I made sure that the artists didn't ask unrealistic prices for them for two reasons really one that you want the artists to sell and they're not famous so they're not gonna get a huge amount for it and secondly the the member of the public can come at the shop and say great I bought a piece of original art and it didn't cost me that much and that's such a wonderful thing
yes mm mm yes
so that's what keeps people coming back keeps the artists coming back and keeps the erm buyers coming back
yes
so there you are but I mean they used to very interesting picture up there
oh
was that something that you did?
no no that was my mother's actually
oh
erm it was always in her lounge
right
and erm when she died I said I'd really love that and it I think it goes rather well in here with the with the dark beams and other things
oh it does definitely
erm I just I just love it I love paintings and pictures which are not too definite and cos you can keep looking at them and see different things

yes absolutely well the horizon and you're looking towards the horizon and I was listening to a video by erm my I I go to on a Monday for erm an art course and there was one by someone called who's really quite good I didn't realise I saw her website last night and she was talking about horizons and how everybody likes horizons and looking towards them because everybody wants to look into the future and be elevated by what they see and imagine what's beyond that side
oh yes yes yes yes
and it sort of it's sort of romantic version erm those do you think they were hanging on those?
I think they must have been but they're just just there I suppose
yes yes take down away or something
yes
it's a nice isolated scene
yes
it's the sort of scene you get over the talking from to it's that sort of thing
yes yeah
in the there is a river which is wonderful
yes
so erm so what now now you're retired then what are your hobbies here?
I don't have too many hobbies I'm afraid erm I did go to an art group well it was a class
right
er our teacher was lovely and he but he was a commercial artist and he got too much work which was lovely for him
right good for him yeah
erm and then we continued to meet as a group but to be honest I never wanted to to do any painting
really?
no it didn't a lot of them would say oh I can't wait to get going with the painting
right
I just didn't feel like that I think perhaps although I did one or two things which I was amazed at
yeah
erm I I'm not artistic really I don't have a gift for it and I think I'm always a little bit worried about wasting time and being dissatisfied with what I've done

well yes it putting yourself in the right situation for it er teaches completely differently to anyone I've ever met erm what she does is she gives you exercises to do and that sounds really boring erm for me if if someone had told me that I would never have gone to the class right
no yeah
it's very hard to explain she's very insidious in her ways of getting you to do things and you don't realise that you're doing them you see
yes right

so erm she showed us a picture last week of a of erm well several erm pictures of of the New York erm skyline the Chicago skyline and they were all in silhouette so they were just black and she asked us using a rigger and a flat brush to erm gave us a demonstration she does a demonstration to everyone very very simple to just try some brushstrokes with these brushes to make this erm skyline or make a skyline up
mm

well honestly it it I mean says to me you can sell that he said it's so good you could sell it nice it was an exercise erm and erm but were producing things they could sell just with these two brushes by doing things not planning just letting it happen
no oh
and erm she paints horizon pictures but it's very much it's very similar to the atmospheric work in that painting up on the wall where you've got the sky and and so on so you might enjoy that class
yes I don't think I'll go
no I I came to the conclusion that really I like being with people
yeah
when I go to an art class I mean you have but basically it's not chatting I like talking
yes

oh it's lovely to talk to you it really is and I I actually approached the library long before I got interested in this I approached the library in and asked them if erm if I could run the art of conversation classes and erm what we would do is just sit down and choose a topic or several topics depending on which one wore out the quickest and talk about it because there were an awful lot of people around who want to have a conversation but when you're in a a partnership for a long time you sort of almost become the other person you were actually thinking what they're thinking and you actually don't have as good a conversation as you might do with a stranger which is obvious really you don't know the stranger do you?
mm yes yes yes
so I wanted to start it and erm they say well we we do this knitting and nattering
oh

and I said no it's not it's not gossip what we're talking about is we might actually discuss erm for instance what's going on at the conservative conference or talk about women priests in the church or my goodness anything
mm

but they just couldn't seem to and they said would you be charging for this? and I said well obviously I'd have to ask people for the money in order us to pay for the room I can't just you know so I would do it free but so I was thinking about that but no erm they said well we we'll put it on the board with the friends of the library but when I thought they were doing origami and knitting and nattering I said no I want to raise the game a bit and talk about something else so erm
yeah
it did it fell on stony ground
yes well what I do I have quite a lot of friends and I seemed to have filled the diary with you know meeting one or two the one I go for a walk with and one I and couple I meet for coffee
yes ah yes
and I suppose my other interest apart from gardening and stuff
yes getting things done
yes erm and and also I want to be free to to go out with say it's a lovely day or something
yes of course that's it
erm so I don't want to to tie myself down too much
no
erm I do go to keep fit on a Friday morning
right
I've been away so I haven't been for a while but that is quite important I suppose
when do you do that then ?
I go to church hall
oh yes I went for a couple of weeks the dancing to music thing?
well it's very dancey isn't it?
yes it is yes
yes
and I kept going the wrong way so I had to stop
oh well I do all the time and and some of us do perennially perpetually
yes
erm but is so nice
yes she is she's very nice
I I like the fact that it's on in the morning you see because the one I went to moved to the afternoon
yes
and although it was a better workout it was somebody called she does quite a lot of erm classes
oh right
I don't I didn't like having to keep myself sort of relatively inactive in the morning to conserve my energy for the afternoon
oh right
cos I do have limited energy
yes I well we all do when we get older
yes
I mean we all do yeah
so this one is fine it's at ten well you know ten o'clock on a Friday
yeah ten o'clock yes
and erm yeah we all I think we all do it in our own way and have our own standard
yes yes well I joined when I left the shop but then I but then I thought I I did try but I was going the wrong way so often and and there is a class that I really like to
uhu
which is in the afternoon again I'm not afternoons either I mean it's in the afternoon and erm it's it's a lot of dancing it's a lot of it but I do want to do dancing you see
uhu
erm but erm I've never been very good at dancing as a team member I seem to go in the opposite direction a bit like my painting
I'm not a team player I don't think I'm an individual and unfortunately you know that comes with its limitations erm
yes
and so I I did pay for the oh I paid for a long session with her long sessions with her erm but unfortunately erm and I paid for the keep fit society or whatever it was
mm
but erm I had to pull out erm at the time I was I was I was ill for three or four weeks with with dizziness and then I just said oh anymore so that was that erm all very amicable
mm
but it's a nice group isn't it?
it is they're very friendly and my other interest of course is is the church
oh right
I'm I'm very active
oh tell me about is it St George's ?
yes
yes
yes well erm I don't I I said I didn't want to belong to the church council I've done that elsewhere and it all seems very intensive here
oh right
they're very much delegated to them by by the vicar who I have a great deal of respect for erm I go to er the home group
right
which is only monthly and I'm in prayer circle which means you get requests for prayers emailed through to pray for the people
right oh right oh
it's very good actually
I hadn't thought of doing praying by email before
well it used to be that you've you've you were in a chain and you phoned but it was when everybody got email there's one person in the chain who doesn't have email so she has to be phoned
oh did you? email
but it does mean that everybody gets the prayer request simultaneously or you know they switch on
yes yeah
and if if you're away it doesn't matter too cos you know the others are doing it anyway
yes yeah
but that is something which is is tremendous and it actually means that I do pray every day and not just when I have a bit of time
yes I know

and erm so that is good erm for for many reasons and also on a Sunday occasionally erm I'm part of the prayer ministry team which means that if somebody wants a prayer at the service you pray with them like a standard prayer
yes right
erm and otherwise oh yes the other thing is that I order the bible reading fellowship booklets on behalf of the church
oh right
you've heard of them I'm sure parts
erm yes I have yes I think so yes
yes and they're still going strong
are they? oh right
and that was that is something I do
yeah yeah
but erm otherwise I just turn up and I I sometimes have helped with the with the decoration of the church but I'm not very flower arranging erm expert you know
sort of person
I like to stick them in a vase and enjoy them

they look lovely in that vase I'd I'd love to get er a sketchpad now not even a pad or sketch it but just blob on some different you know just blob on some different colours there very sort of and erm
yes they are lovely aren't they?
they're gorgeous and of course you've got the brush strokes you can see the brush strokes can't you?
yes
well I should have a go at that
well I might just take a photo of them and then when I when I can I'll erm paint them
yeah and the stems are rather nice because a bit distorted in that vase aren't they because it's so curved?
yes yes
well it's a rose pink colour it's it's amazing it's really nice
yes
erm so erm we I I don't really remember it I don't know whether it's do you remember a fashion show being staged in church years ago?
no I don't think I was here then

well there was a young from hospital and erm it was all trad she was she ran a Christian group at and and I used to go erm years ago and erm I'm sure she was involved in it and and that's how I got the invitation and they they actually put erm it was when they had the pews they actually put boards all across the top of the pews and the models walked all over them over the pews
oh

and I remember thinking at the time this is a bit strange for a church and they were selling you know I'm I'm terribly mindful of I mean we're talking about erm seventy-eight erm nineteen eighty early nineteen eighty we're talking and I remember you know what Jesus said about the moneylenders and and transactions going on in church of course nobody takes any notice about that now we've got we've got cafes we've got erm gift shops and all
yes

I can't believe it how how the church as an institution has divorced itself from Christianity and I find that very hard to to to take on board erm and yeah so yes I was I remember being absolutely amazed and I went to it was a very nice erm I think maybe a lot of these erm items had been made locally erm I bought a skirt which I wore for a long time a patchwork skirt which was very nice but I I often say to my husband he said do you really think that they would have allowed have allowed that to happen at ? erm because the other thing too about church was er just very briefly be I'm sure you've had enough by now but erm just very briefly
it's very interesting
well erm my husband and I met twenty-one years ago
oh yes
and erm we were both erm you know quite mature by then and er he and his parents had lived in this area for years and he'd been an altar boy erm for years at church
uhu

and erm he erm we were we were living in erm and erm we were going to get married and and he said well I'd like to get married at church erm although I haven't been because I'm you know er well he used to go to the eight o'clock quite rightly but he hadn't been for a while
mm

and it was during the interregnum and we rang up and the secretary told me there was no chance we could get married at church I thought when I thought think of the time after my mum died and and erm for four years I to my father while he was vicar of and I had to I was nursing full time and I was cleaning the house making all the coffee for taking all the over the phone letting the people out in the hospital and having the undertaker ring me up when I got home for four years I don't know how I survived
goodness me
